comments:
When our perspective is starting, the Repositories View checks for a Lists view
(using WorkbenchPage.findView) and adds it as a listener to the Repositories
view.  Whenever the Lists View starts it does a findView for the Repositiories
View and adds itself as a listener.  This works without a warning when starting
and stopping the views.  But, when the perspective is initially opened we get
this warning of a recursive attempt to create the parts.  The findView method
seems to operate differently when the perspective is initializing and seems to
be doing a createPart for some reason.  This warning does not occur with 3.0.2.

org.eclipse.ui.PartInitException: Warning: Detected recursive attempt by part

One of the parts needs to be created first. findPart creates the target part,
and they can't both say "create the other view before me".

Eclipse 3.0.2 returned a partially initialized part, which was a bug (someone
*WILL* throw an exception the first time they try to use the part - which
happened all over the place in 3.0.2). The correct behavior is for the inner
findPart to return null. The exception isn't strictly necessary - it is intended
as a convenience to help view authors clean up cyclic dependencies between views.

There are two ways to fix the cycle:
1. Use findViewReference rather than findView (the former does not force part
creation). OR:
2. If the list view doesn't find the repo view at creation-time, attach an
IPartListener to the page, and attach its listener to the repo view when it gets
the repo view's PartOpened event. (This works because partOpened gets fired
AFTER the part is fully initialized, whereas createPartControl is called as part
of initialization). This is preferable to method 1 because in this case the repo
view doesn't even need to know about the list view.

It would be possible to remove the warning from the log with no ill-effects, but
then cyclic dependancies like this one would go undetected and unfixed. I've
filed bug 99779 to cover the (inevitable) suggestion to omit the warning from
the log.

Since the actual bug is in a non-Eclipse view, I'm closing this as INVALID. All
Eclipse classes are functioning correctly.
